repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Health System Reform Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory,
            and project sustainability is rated likely. The overall
            performance of the World Bank is rated satisfactory, while
            Borrower performance is rated highly satisfactory. This
            section analyzes lessons learned from two Bank operations,
            the Health System Reform Project (the SECAL) and the Health
            System Reform Technical Assistance Project (the TAL), acting
            together to support one reform process. Some of the lessons
            learned in this section might also apply to the SECAL and
            are presented in the SECAL ICR (report no. 26236) and vice
            versa. Lessons learned are organized in three sections: (1)
            overall comments on project design and implementation; (2)
            issues related to the separation of functions, resource
            allocation and reimbursement mechanisms; and (3) the
            redefined primary health care model. They include: 1) Strict
            coherence between the TAL and the SECAL must be a result of
            the parallel design, and its maintenance during project life
            a result of the supervision process that brings "tuning
            up" to the operations. Strict synergy of both
            project's implementation is necessary to successfully
            support the reform agenda. 2) The TAL financed some
            activities that were not used for policy change under the
            SECAL since those were regarded as pilots without any real
            consensus around the policy changes they were proposing to
            implement. 3) When the Bank acts as a catalyst to change in
            the preparation phase, sufficient support should be provided
            to ensure that technical issues are well addressed during
            project implementation.4) To measure the impact and outcome
            of each activity of the reform project, it is not enough to
            define monitoring and performance indicators at appraisal.
            5) A reform process supported by parallel SECAL and TAL
            operations should develop a specific strategy to deal with
            the political aspects of a reform. TA packages should be
            such that allow for technical developments to be easily
            linked to the policy arena for implementation. 6) It is
            important to closely collaborate and coordinate efforts
            among the Bank, the Institution and the PCU in order to
            achieve the originally proposed goals and diminish the risk
            of misunderstandings that might end changing the course of
            the reform. 7) Successful implementation of information
            systems in a reform project require a strong internal
            champion and a clear operational need to guarantee timely
            and successful implementation.
